title: 114_s2392
content: The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" limits the removal of Medicare Advantage providers by MA organizations. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" restricts MA organizations from removing providers without cause starting in 2017. Cause for removal includes medical negligence or violation of legal requirements. The "Medicare Advantage Bill of Rights Act of 2015" prohibits MA organizations from removing providers without cause, such as medical negligence or violation of legal requirements. Beginning in 2017, an MA organization offering an MA plan can only remove a provider from the network for reasons not specified in the Act 60 days before the start of the plan year. Beginning in 2017, an MA organization offering an MA plan can only remove a provider from the network for reasons not specified in the Act 60 days before the start of the plan year. The removal must follow a fair notice and appeal process established by the Secretary. The Secretary shall establish a process for MA organizations to provide reasons for removing a provider from their network. This process applies to removals occurring after the effective date of a final rule and replaces the termination process under section 422.202(a) of title 42. The Secretary establishes a process for MA organizations to explain provider removals from their network, replacing the termination process under section 422.202(a) of title 42. Before a provider is removed from an MA plan network, participants must receive a 60-day notice. Before a provider is removed from an MA plan network, participants must receive a 60-day notice including names and contact information of alternative in-network providers offering similar services. The annual notice of change for an MA plan must include information on available in-network providers offering similar services, options for continuing treatment with a removed provider, and customer service contact numbers for plan changes. The MA organization offering an MA plan must provide service telephone numbers for individuals to access information about network changes. Additionally, the annual notice of change must include notifications about provider removals and continuity of care requirements for individuals receiving services. Beginning with plan year 2017, MA organizations must provide transparency in measures used to establish or modify provider networks in MA plans. This includes including specific information in the annual bid information. Providers have the right to decline participation in an MA plan network. Beginning in 2017, MA organizations offering MA plans must disclose information on the measures used to establish or modify provider networks. This includes details on the quality and efficiency measures, such as specifications, methodology, and sample size, which must be included in the annual bid information and on the MA plan's website. The MA organization must disclose information on measures used to establish or modify provider networks for MA plans, including quality and efficiency measures. This information must be included in the annual bid and on the MA plan's website. The disclosed information shall not include any individually identifiable information of providers or suppliers of services. Enforcement measures for noncompliance are also outlined in the Social Security Act. Enforcement measures for noncompliance with provider network disclosure requirements in MA plans are outlined in the Social Security Act, including sanctions for failing to comply with specific sections. The Social Security Act outlines enforcement measures for noncompliance with provider network disclosure requirements in Medicare Advantage plans, including sanctions. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must ensure that the Medicare Advantage Compare Tool considers the preferences and utilization needs of individuals within a year of this Act's enactment. SEC. 3. NETWORK ADEQUACY. In plan year 2017, Medicare Advantage organizations offering MA plans must consider factors like anticipated enrollment, types of services, provider availability, and location when establishing a plan network. In establishing a plan network, Medicare Advantage organizations offering MA plans must consider factors such as provider availability, location, and timely provision of care. The Secretary will seek input from various stakeholders in applying network access adequacy standards. In applying network access adequacy standards, the Secretary seeks input from stakeholders like patient advocacy groups, service providers, and Medicare Advantage plans. Each plan year, Medicare Advantage organizations must certify that their network providers can meet enrollees' needs and report on each MA plan offered. Each plan year, Medicare Advantage organizations must report on various aspects of their MA plans, including average wait times, utilization of out-of-network providers, and average cost per patient for primary and specialty care. Additionally, organizations must certify network adequacy before the annual election period. The Medicare Advantage organization must certify the accuracy of provider directories and ensure network adequacy for each plan offered. The Secretary will review the network of each MA plan at least once every 3 years or when a material change occurs. Enforcement includes amendments to the Social Security Act.
